title: Give Users security and confidence
description: 真実を隠蔽することは、暗号通貨でよく見られるフィッシング攻撃や詐欺が、人々に自分の利益に反する行動を取らせる方法です。

f6_assessments.q0: This seems like an awesome proposal that could make smart contracts accessible to users rather than just trusting that a developer has implemented in code what their advertisement says. The resulting CIP if accepted could really drive Cardano to the forefront of blockchain smart contracts. For the small amount they are asking for it seems we can't afford not to explore this.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers have detailed their extensive relevant experience and obviously have a passion for this. They have presented a detailed and well articulated plan to produce a CIP which could really provide the type of confidence Smart contracts need to thrive.
The one question I would have is that given the relatively small amount of funds they are asking for, when converted to hours at the $100/hr rate they discuss, it is not that many hours. Could they not compress delivery of the whole project to a shorter timeframe than 12 months for the CIP? Smart contracts are imminent, why wait 12 months to produce a CIP that may fundamentally change how we deal with them?
f6_assessments.q2: A detailed plan is provided against which progress can easily be measured. In the end, success would be acceptance of the CIP produced.

f6_assessments.q0: The project proposal presents the problem of the smart contract not bridging the gap between a legal contract and a smart contract code. The goal of the metadata challenge is to implement anti-counterfeit and traceability solutions. Thus the project is within the challenge settings.  Implementation of the Ricardian contract standard and the development toolkit will have an unlimited impact on the Cardano ecosystem since it'll create a bridge between the legislation managing applications and Cardano platform capabilities by removing the room for fraud.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer team describes the relevant experience.  However, I could not locate the relevant references that support that. The proposer provided the links to the projects he worked on, but it's not easily verifiable that the team worked on those projects. Also, it would be helpful to describe the extended team and link to their credentials. 

The proposal outlines the complete roadmap for the project. But I think it's important to clearly understand the target audience's needs that might utilize the Ricardian contract in the software that already exists or is being developed. I couldn't locate the mentions of the consultations needed outside the Cardano community or smart contract developers, or if such would be beneficial to identify the real-world needs. It will help if the proposal has a distinctive strategy to gather all-rounded feedback.

Although the plan outlines the formalization of the existing standards and tools on the market, the proposer mentioned that the list of the presented tools and standards is not exhaustive, so it would be important to discuss the potential risks of the research phase taking longer than anticipated. 

It would be reasonable to specify further technical details that match the budget breakdown, such as the community engagement expenses. And possibly indicate if there is any budget required to host and run the prototype.
f6_assessments.q2: The project milestone definitely describes the plan and goes beyond the three-month scope. The standard draft and all related tools are planned to be open-sourced, will be published to GitHub. Perhaps having some drafts or UI mockups before the engagement of the community to keep the discussion in the timeline and scope would be beneficial. Also, it would help to follow the project progress. As mentioned before, the research phase timeline is a little concerning. Since the full scope of the research field, expected results, and potential risks are not sufficiently presented.

f6_assessments.q0: With the introduction of smart contracts comes the potential for new types of fraud and scams. This proposal identifies an existing methodology (Ricardian Contracts) that can do so within the metadata. This approach would add value to the cardano ecosystem by increasing user confidence in smart contracts by coupling a contract's code with its human-readable description. This project synthesizes existing approaches and standards to address this F6: Metadata Challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: Having extensive experience in this domain, the proposing team is well positioned to design, build, and implement their proposal (including decades-long experience in the financial data science sector and having gone through the Plutus Pioneer program) and links out to examples. The budget is well defined and reasonable and aligns with a well defined timeline.
f6_assessments.q2: The problem is adequately described, the solution is generally defined in the proposal and links to additional resources offered for Ricardian Contracts and other elements. Additional development of a plan to test the effectiveness of the system would strengthen the proposal. Specifically, some number of smart contracts built using this system wherein 3 out of 10 are designed to defraud the non-developer user/tester--with the ability of the tester to successfully identify the fraudulent contracts as a potential metric or part of a larger metric for the success of the program.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is aligned with the sample direction in the challenge brief titled "Auditable decentralized document workflows".  The proposers intent is to create a toolkit or workflow that makes integrating real-world legal/procedural contracts with smart contracts easier.  The goal is to tie various operational steps or phases that have calendar events associated with them (deadlines) that have been agreed upon in a business contract to code in a Cardano smart contract.
f6_assessments.q1: I would have liked to give 5 stars here but the proposers did not provide much in the way of proof of the numerous skills they claim in the proposal.  Some LinkedIn links, or awards/commendations available for inspection on the web, etc. would have been helpful and should be provided at a later date.  I didn't give less than 4 stars because the proposers are up front that the funding request is for a "pilot project" (3 months) to determine the shape and direction of the full project.  That combined with the intriguing ideas presented in the proposal, backed with reference document links, left me with a net positive impression of their skill levels.  Voters will have to make up their own minds up as to whether or not I made the right call in this particular assessment note.
f6_assessments.q2:
Had this been a request for the full project I would have been deterred by the lack of calendar based user acquisition and client integration targets and milestones provided ("client integration target" = the number of businesses willing to use their tool on the Cardano blockchain).  But as I said, this is a request to fund a "pilot project" so these more concrete metrics are not applicable here.  They have given a few development targets that can be used to assess the progress of the project.  I would suggest in the future they provide a few more metrics for their proposal than they have, just to make it easier to assess their proposals auditability.

NOTE: I view this project as follows.  Best case assuming the proposers succeed with their follow-up funding requests, it results in the open source SDK code and tools that can be used to make integrating real world business contracts with actionable Cardano smart contracts easier, and that would be a really important tool to assist the adoption of the Cardano ecosystem by the global business community.  Worst case, they provide valuable open source research into discovering better or friendlier ways to help companies and developers integrate their business logic into Cardano smart contracts.
